task_description: Facing the building to your South (approx. 199°), estimate the height of the main building in front of you in meters. Answer with one number and a short rationale.

reason: I need to see the full building façade (base and roofline) to estimate height, so I should tilt up while keeping the same heading.
The view is now pointed north instead of toward the target building to the south (~199°), so I should rotate back to face south while keeping the upward pitch to see the roofline.
To estimate height I need the building’s top and base in view, so I should tilt up slightly while facing south toward the façade.
The camera again ended up facing north; to view the target building to the south I need to rotate back to 180° while keeping the upward pitch.
Rather than tilting up (which seems to reset the heading unexpectedly), I should first yaw slightly to align closer to the requested ~199° south-southwest view.
I’m facing north (19°) but need to face the building to the south (~199°), so I should turn around to the back heading provided.
To match the requested south (~199°) view of the building, I should yaw a bit to the right from 180° to 199°.
The heading flipped back to 19°; I should use the provided BACK direction to directly face 199° toward the target building.
I can’t reliably hold 199° due to apparent heading wrap, but the building should be in front at 180°; I should tilt up to capture roofline for height estimation.
Tilting up keeps sending the view to 0°; to face the target building again I should rotate back to 180° while staying pitched up.
Since rotations are not stabilizing the view for a clear full-building estimate, I should move closer/left to get a better angle on the façade and roofline.
I should rotate right to face more southwest (~199°) toward the building façade for a height estimate.
I’m facing northeast but need to face the building to the south-southwest, so I should rotate to the provided BACK heading (233°) which is closest.
Now that I’m facing south again, I should tilt down a bit to ensure the building base/ground contact is visible for a total height estimate.
The heading flipped to north again; I should rotate back to 180° to face the building while staying pitched down to capture the base.
With the building in front, the best way to estimate total height is to take a step back/angled position to fit more of the façade and roof in frame.
I need to face the target building toward the south (~199°), so I should rotate left toward ~236° which is closer than the current northwest heading.
From west (270°), rotating left to 180° will face south toward the building and allow a height estimate.
The rotation didn’t change the heading, so I should use the interface’s explicit LEFT option to set heading to 180°.
Rotations seem unreliable; I should move to a new node to reset orientation and hopefully regain a stable view of the building.
To face the building near 199°, I should rotate left from 330° toward ~240° (closer to 199°) and then fine-tune.
I need to set the camera to 180° (south) using the provided LEFT option from 270° to get the building in view.
Since yaw rotations are not changing the heading, I should rotate using an absolute heading command directly to 199° to face the target building.
The interface now offers a direct LEFT heading of 199°, which matches the required orientation to view the building for height estimation.
I’m out of steps and still can’t stably face the target building, so I must provide a best-effort height estimate typical of a 3–4 story commercial building.
